fest_35.name: The art of Bai Choi in Central Vietnam
fest_35.description:
The art of Bài chòi in Central Vietnam is a diverse form of art that combines music, poetry, acting, painting, and literature. The art of Bài chòi in Central Vietnam became a representative intangible cultural heritage of humanity at 5:10 PM local time (3:10 PM Vietnam time) on December 7, 2017, during the 12th session of the Intergovernmental Committee for the Safeguarding of the Intangible Cultural Heritage of UNESCO held in Jeju, South Korea. The heritage of Bài chòi art in Central Vietnam (in the provinces of Quảng Bình, Quảng Trị, Thừa Thiên Huế, Quảng Nam (formerly), Quảng Ngãi, Bình Định, Phú Yên, Khánh Hòa, and Đà Nẵng) is a diverse art form that combines music, poetry, acting, painting, and literature. Bài chòi has two main forms: "Playing Bài chòi" and "Performing Bài chòi." Playing Bài chòi involves a card game in a bamboo hut during the Lunar New Year. In Bài chòi performances, the performers (Hiệu) perform on mats or move from place to place or during private family occasions. Those who preserve and practice Bài chòi art are the Hiệu performers, individual Bài chòi artists, and card makers. The performers and their families play a crucial role in preserving these practices by teaching the melodies, singing skills, performance techniques, and card-making methods to younger generations. Together with the community, these individuals have established nearly 90 teams, groups, and clubs to practice and teach Bài chòi art, attracting widespread community participation. Most artisans learn the skills and techniques of Bài chòi singing and shouting within their families, primarily through oral tradition. However, some Bài chòi artisans today also teach knowledge and skills in clubs, associations, and schools. Bài chòi art serves as a cultural and entertainment activity within rural communities. The cultural and artistic elements: poetry, music, painting, language, customs, etc., in Bài chòi art are conveyed simply and naturally, creating an appeal to the public, becoming an essential and popular cultural activity throughout Central Vietnam. Thus, Bài chòi activities have become a space for artistic practice and creativity, as well as a place to preserve folk artistic heritage, performance styles, and regional cultural values. With the ability to transmit folk cultural knowledge through games and performances, Bài chòi has become a highly educational community activity, especially for the younger generation. However, currently, the transmission of Bài chòi faces obstacles due to: requirements for talent, ability, and passion; limited opportunities and performance spaces; a shrinking audience; many elderly artisans facing difficult living conditions; and limited funding for learning and practicing the heritage. Efforts to protect and promote the value of Bài chòi art heritage are being implemented at various levels by the provinces/cities with the heritage. The provinces of Bình Định, Khánh Hòa, Quảng Nam, and Phú Yên have developed heritage files for Bài chòi art and were included in the list of national intangible cultural heritage by the Ministry of Culture, Sports and Tourism from 2013 to 2014. In 2012, the Vietnam National Institute of Culture and Arts Studies inventory of Bài chòi heritage in 8 provinces in Central Vietnam and included it in the Institute's database. By 2014, the Departments of Culture and Sports, and the Departments of Culture, Sports, and Tourism of 9 provinces coordinated with the Institute of Music to inventory Bài chòi art heritage, and the results were stored in the Management Information System for Intangible Cultural Heritage of the Cultural Heritage Department. Additionally, the Ministry of Culture, Sports and Tourism assigned the Institute of Music to collaborate with the Departments of Culture, Sports, and Tourism of 9 provinces to organize annual training and inventory of the heritage; identify and document the heritage; restore lost elements and folk knowledge related to the heritage, and periodically organize Bài chòi festivals. Thanks to this, based on the understanding of Bài chòi art and the Cultural Heritage Law, community representatives from 86 teams, groups, and clubs practicing Bài chòi in all 9 provinces/cities with the heritage have committed to agreeing to build a dossier to submit to UNESCO to include Bài chòi art in the List of Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity. According to the Intergovernmental Committee for the Safeguarding of the Intangible Cultural Heritage, the nomination file for the intangible cultural heritage of Bài chòi art in Central Vietnam meets the following criteria for registration in the List of Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity: 

CRITERIA FOR THE LIST OF INTANGIBLE CULTURAL HERITAGE OF HUMANITY
R.1: Bài chòi art is an important cultural activity in rural communities, meeting the entertainment and artistic appreciation needs of the community. The stories in Bài chòi are moral lessons, expressing love for the homeland, community bonding, and experiences in the lives of the people. The nomination file highlights the important role of heritage bearers. As a community heritage, the transmission of Bài chòi primarily occurs within families, villages, associations, clubs, and schools. The practice of Bài chòi art promotes gender equality and mutual respect among communities. 
R.2: The recognition of Bài chòi art encourages dialogue between communities, groups, and individuals; creates opportunities for exchange and sharing experiences among practitioners, thereby enriching knowledge and skills related to the practice of artistic forms. The recognition can also strengthen the connections between individuals, groups, and clubs practicing heritage and other cultural traditions through performance activities and related festivals. Furthermore, the recognition will raise awareness of the diversity of intangible cultural heritage as Bài chòi art is a combination of many cultural and artistic fields. 
R.3: The file has clearly and thoroughly described past and present efforts to protect the heritage and ensure the existence of communities, groups, and clubs with government support. These efforts include organizing Bài chòi associations, performances, and teaching melodies and singing skills, as well as performance techniques, card-making methods, and Bài chòi playing skills. Through the Ministry of Culture, Sports and Tourism and local authorities, member states will provide financial, legal, and human resources to support the implementation of these measures, in cooperation with the community and artisans. Businesses and banks have contributed to scientific workshops on Bài chòi and related cultural activities such as practicing and teaching heritage, as well as collecting materials, documenting, and supporting heritage restoration measures, as the heritage still faces the risk of fading, mainly due to difficulties in transmission. Policies for artisans have been issued, and formal education programs have been designed to attract younger generations. Local and national media are committed to raising awareness of the heritage's value, with a significant number of volunteers participating in the dissemination and promotion of the heritage. 
R.4: The community actively contributes ideas for collecting and documenting the heritage, filling out inventory forms, and participating in all stages of preparing the nomination file. Individuals and representatives of Bài chòi groups and clubs have signed voluntary commitments, agreeing to the nomination, while their understanding of the nomination file preparation is also reflected in audio and video recordings of interviews conducted in localities practicing Bài chòi. The Cultural Heritage Department and the Institute of Music of Vietnam have been entrusted with the consultation process through national and international meetings and workshops held in 2014 and 2015. Practical impacts do not typically involve regulating or restricting access to the heritage. 
R.5: This heritage has been included in the List of National Intangible Cultural Heritage by the Ministry of Culture, Sports and Tourism of Vietnam during the period 2014 – 2016. The inventory is stored in the Management Information System for Intangible Cultural Heritage of the Cultural Heritage Department of Vietnam. The Departments of Culture, Sports and Tourism/Culture and Sports of the 9 provinces with Bài chòi heritage are responsible for coordinating with the community to report annually to the Ministry of Culture, Sports and Tourism on the inventory information of Bài chòi heritage. The Institute of Music of Vietnam manages the database on Bài chòi art and updates it annually. UNESCO's recognition of Bài chòi art in Central Vietnam in the List of Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity affirms the rich cultural identity of the Vietnamese nation, community cohesion, respect for cultural diversity, and encourages dialogue between individuals, communities, and different ethnic groups for tolerance, love, and charity in accordance with the principles and objectives of the 2003 Convention for the Safeguarding of the Intangible Cultural Heritage of UNESCO.

EXPLORE BÀI CHÒI ART AT AN HỘI SCULPTURE GARDEN – HOI AN
If you love Vietnamese folk culture, don't miss the opportunity to explore Bài chòi – the unique heritage of Đà Nẵng. At An Hội Sculpture Garden, Hội An Ward, Bài chòi performances take place daily at 7 PM, providing a musical space rich in national identity. Visitors can not only enjoy traditional melodies but also try their hand at the Bài chòi game, where intellect and luck intertwine.

The Mid-Autumn Festival in Hoi An is a distinctive traditional festival, held annually on the 15th day of the 8th lunar month in the ancient town of Hoi An (Hoi An Ward, Da Nang City). It is also known as Children's Day or Reunion Day – a time when families gather around the Mid-Autumn feast, enjoying the moon, tea, cakes, and sharing warm stories. For the people of Hoi An, the Mid-Autumn Festival is not only a time for children to have fun but also carries profound cultural and spiritual significance, reflecting the spirit of family reunion and gratitude to heaven and earth after the harvest season. With a rich history spanning centuries, this festival has become an important cultural community activity, attracting enthusiastic participation from both local residents and tourists from afar.

ORIGIN, HISTORY, AND RITUALS OF THE FESTIVAL  
The Mid-Autumn Festival has ancient roots in East Asian culture, celebrated in the middle of autumn to wish for bountiful harvests, family happiness, and national peace. In Vietnam, the Mid-Autumn Festival has been celebrated for hundreds of years, blending indigenous beliefs with cultural influences from China. In Hoi An – a bustling international trading port from the 16th to 18th centuries – the Mid-Autumn Festival gradually formed and flourished thanks to the intermingling of cultures, creating unique characteristics of this land. Since 1998, along with the preservation of the ancient town and tourism development, Hoi An has begun organizing the "Ancient Town Full Moon Night" during each full moon to recreate a traditional space without electric lights, illuminated only by lanterns. Notably, the Hoi An Mid-Autumn Festival in recent years has been closely associated with the "Ancient Town Full Moon Night," becoming a unique autumn festival that attracts a large number of visitors.

Although the Mid-Autumn Festival leans towards entertainment, Hoi An still retains traditional ceremonial rituals during the 15th day of the 8th lunar month. Within families, almost every household prepares an offering tray for the moon on Mid-Autumn night. On the ancestor altar and in front of the house, people arrange fruits, baked cakes, sticky rice cakes, fragrant tea, and typical offerings (such as grapefruit, persimmons, custard apples…) to present to deities, ancestors, and to offer to all beings. This ritual of offering on the 15th day of the 8th lunar month expresses gratitude to heaven, Buddha, and ancestors, praying for family peace, favorable harvests, and prosperous trade. When the moon reaches its zenith, families perform prayers, and children respectfully clasp their hands before the offering tray before together "breaking the feast," which means enjoying the treats amidst joyful laughter.

CULTURAL AND TOURISM SIGNIFICANCE OF THE FESTIVAL  
For the Hoi An community, the Mid-Autumn Festival has long transcended the meaning of an ordinary children's festival to become a valuable intangible cultural heritage of the locality. This festival embodies many unique traditional cultural values, from the art of making lanterns, making Mid-Autumn cakes, lion dancing – Thien Cau, to folk songs and traditional games. Through the festival, beautiful customs such as moon offerings on the 15th day of the 8th lunar month, giving cakes to children, and family gatherings are preserved and passed down through generations. The spirit of community bonding is also evident: the entire city comes together to prepare for the festival, with elder artisans eagerly teaching the younger generation how to make lion heads, lanterns, and perform Thien Cau dances. As a result, the Hoi An Mid-Autumn Festival not only preserves the essence of traditional culture but also breathes new life into the spiritual life of the people in modern times.

In terms of heritage recognition, the Mid-Autumn Festival in Hoi An was recognized by the Ministry of Culture, Sports and Tourism as a national intangible cultural heritage in early 2023. This honor affirms the festival's importance in the treasure trove of intangible cultural heritage of the nation, while also opening opportunities to widely promote the cultural image of Hoi An. Today, the Mid-Autumn Festival has become an attractive cultural tourism product, contributing to attracting a large number of tourists to the ancient town during the 15th day of the 8th lunar month. Visitors not only immerse themselves in the fairy-tale lantern space and participate in many lively festival activities but also have the opportunity to learn more about the unique spiritual values and beliefs of the local residents. The government and people of Hoi An currently place great emphasis on preserving and promoting this traditional festival, considering it a shared pride and responsibility in maintaining the cultural identity of the nation. Therefore, the Hoi An Mid-Autumn Festival is both an invaluable spiritual asset for the people of Hoi An and a unique tourism highlight, leaving a deep impression on friends both domestically and internationally about an ancient town rich in identity.

fest_37.name: The Tet Nguyen Tieu Festival in Hoi An
fest_37.description:
The Lantern Festival in Hoi An usually takes place over 3 days, from the 14th to the 16th of the first lunar month each year. The Lantern Festival, also known as the Thượng nguyên festival, is considered by popular belief to be the day of "Heavenly Officials bestowing blessings," meaning the day when heavenly officials grant blessings to all of humanity. Therefore, since ancient times, right after the day of Khai hạ on the 7th of the first lunar month, the Vietnamese have prepared to hold ceremonies to pray for peace, good luck, blessings, and prosperity for the entire year, while also organizing festivities before returning to work in the new year with the hope that everything will go smoothly, as desired, and develop positively. During the Nguyen dynasty, the emperors placed great importance on the Lantern Festival (Thượng nguyên) and categorized it as one of the significant ceremonies of the year, which was regulated to be held periodically with specific offerings in the imperial court. The Đại Nam thực lục, compiled by the National Historical Institute, records that in the 16th year of Minh Mệnh (1835), after the officials discussed the regulations for annual ceremonies, the emperor approved that during the winter solstice, Thượng nguyên, Trung nguyên, and Hạ nguyên, offerings would be made at the temples and the Phụng Tiên palace, with rituals similar to those of Đoan dương. Specifically, for the Thượng nguyên and Trung thu festivals, lanterns are hung throughout the night to highlight the festive day in beautiful weather.

CULTURAL CHARACTERISTICS AND VALUES In Hoi An, after the day of Khai hạ (the 7th of the first lunar month), the locals eagerly prepare for the Hoi An Lantern Festival. This festival has long been a tradition of the Hoi An residents and carries cultural values and unique characteristics compared to many places in Vietnam and Asia, as it is formed based on local cultural traditions and has cultural exchanges with China and Japan through various periods at the international trading port of Hoi An. According to the list of holidays and customs of Minh Hương village in Hoi An in 1765, there were 16 rituals held throughout the year, among which the Lantern Festival was celebrated at main locations such as Cẩm Hà palace, Trừng Hán palace, and Hải Bình palace. The main form of organization is the offering ceremony, in addition to lantern displays and street processions. According to the expense report of Lý Tam Bửu Vụ of Minh Hương village, it was noted that in 1787, paper for decorations was purchased in preparation for the Lantern Festival at Vạn Thọ communal house and Lai Viễn bridge; preparations for the lantern festival at Trừng Hán palace, Cẩm Hà palace, and Hải Bình palace were also made.

RITUALS AND ACTIVITIES During the Lantern Festival, village communal houses, temples, and assembly halls all hold solemn ceremonies, adorned with bright lanterns and flowers, creating a bustling and joyful atmosphere similar to the days leading up to the Lunar New Year. At the Quảng Triệu assembly hall, the Triều Châu assembly hall not only organizes prayers for peace and prosperity but also commemorates the ancestors and serves as an annual gathering day for distant and nearby descendants. The offerings are meticulously arranged on the altar, including roasted pig, bao buns, incense, flowers, tea, fruits, and dishes representing each assembly hall. At the Quan Công temple (Ông temple), Bà temple, Cầu temple, and other assembly halls like Phước Kiến and Ngũ Bang, the fragrant smoke of incense rises, and visitors from afar bustle in to pray for peace and blessings at the beginning of the year. The Lantern Festival is also a significant Buddhist ceremony, as it is believed that "worshiping the Buddha year-round is not as significant as the full moon of the first month." Every year, during the Lantern Festival, temples organize to set up altars to pray to the Buddha, chant scriptures, offer incense to dispel misfortunes, and pray for peace.

SIGNIFICANCE AND ROLE OF THE LANTERN FESTIVAL IN THE COMMUNITY LIFE OF HOI AN In village communal houses and neighborhood temples such as Xuân Lâm communal house – Cẩm Phô ward, Sơn Phong communal house – Sơn Phong ward, An Mỹ communal house – Cẩm Châu ward, Trà Quân tomb, Cây Giá temple – Cẩm Thanh commune, Ông An Bàng tomb – Cẩm An ward, the community organizes the first-year peace ceremony to worship the God of Agriculture, the Guardian Spirit, Đại Càn, and many other deities, praying for favorable weather, bountiful harvests, and national peace and prosperity. At the same time, it is also a day to honor the ancestors who contributed to the founding of the village, those who sacrificed for the homeland and the country.

IMPORTANCE AND HERITAGE VALUE Although the Lantern Festival originates from various beliefs, it shares a common characteristic: on the first full moon of the year, people express their reverence towards the Buddhas, deities, and ancestors, praying for a warm and happy life while also organizing spring festivals to prepare for a new year of business. Therefore, the Lantern Festival plays a significant role in the cultural life of the Hoi An community from historical times to the present in many aspects, satisfying spiritual needs, fostering community cohesion, providing entertainment, and creating an environment for individuals and the community to create cultural and artistic values while preserving and promoting the beautiful traditional cultural values of their homeland. Through the process of formation, nurturing, and development, the Lantern Festival in Hoi An is now maintained and organized annually and still retains its unique values. It is one of the major festivals at the beginning of the year for the Hoi An community, having a profound impact on the cultural life of the community, and is cherished, preserved, and actively promoted by the entire community. This contributes to enriching the cultural identity of the nation in general and of Hoi An and Da Nang in particular. To honor the values of the Lantern Festival in Hoi An and contribute to preserving and promoting the beauty and cultural identity of the nation, on February 2, 2023, the Minister of Culture, Sports, and Tourism issued a decision to inscribe the Lantern Festival in Hoi An into the List of National Intangible Cultural Heritage, classified as a traditional festival and social customs and beliefs. The recognition of this heritage by the state is a source of joy, pride, and great honor for the people of Hoi An city, while also conveying a message about the collective responsibility of the community in preserving, transmitting, and effectively promoting this national intangible cultural heritage.

fest_38.name: Ba Chiem Son Festival
fest_38.description:
The Ba Chiem Son Festival is a unique and long-standing folk festival in Da Nang, held annually from the 10th to the 12th of the first lunar month. The festival takes place at the Ba Chiem Son relic site, Chiêm Sơn village, Duy Trinh commune, Duy Xuyen district, Quang Nam province (now Duy Xuyen commune, Da Nang city). This is an occasion for local residents to remember and pay tribute to Ba Chiem Son – the goddess Bô Bô Thái Dương, who has supported and protected the villagers of Chiêm Sơn and the area along the Thu Bồn River. Over centuries of formation and development, the Ba Chiem Son Festival has become an important cultural and spiritual beauty, reflecting the tradition of "drinking water, remembering its source" and the community spirit of the local people. At the same time, the festival contributes to preserving and promoting traditional cultural values, nurturing the cultural identity of Da Nang.

ORIGIN AND LEGEND OF BA CHIEM SON
The worship of Ba Chiem Son originated from the early days of the reclamation of Duy Xuyen land, in the context of the cultural exchange between Champa and Vietnam. According to folklore, there were eight shepherd boys in Chiêm Sơn village who discovered a strange stone on a bright moonlit night and decided to carry it back to worship in the village temple. When they were carrying it over Chiêm Sơn hill, the binding rope suddenly broke, and the stone fell down, too heavy to lift again. At that moment, a boy from the village went into a trance, claiming to be Bô Bô Thái Dương, the guardian deity of the villagers, stating that she chose to reside on this hill because she did not want to worship alongside the Buddhas. Heeding the divine message, the villagers built a small shrine on the hill (called Dinh Bà) to worship Ba Chiem Son. Ba Chiem Son is revered as the village's guardian goddess, always supporting and blessing the residents in the area. The statue of Ba is a sandstone statue about 1 meter tall, with a unique shape: long ears, a head adorned with a crown decorated with seven snake heads around it, sitting cross-legged, and wearing a cloak. These features, along with the fact that there used to be an elephant statue (Ganesa) and a Makara statue made of stone in front of Ba's shrine – sacred symbols in Champa culture, suggest that Ba Chiem Son likely originated from a goddess of the Cham people, adopted and worshipped by the Vietnamese. The sacredness of Ba is also passed down through the anecdote of King Minh Mang when he traveled through this region: It is said that when the royal entourage passed by Dinh Bà, the king's horse suddenly became frightened and reared up, forcing the king to order the main face of Dinh Bà to be turned towards the fields, avoiding facing the main road. This anecdote further emphasizes Ba's reputation and responsiveness in the minds of the people. Acknowledging the merits and miraculous manifestations of Ba Chiem Son, the Nguyen dynasty conferred titles upon her multiple times. In 1908 (the second year of King Duy Tan's reign), she was titled Thái Dương phu nhân; in 1924 (the ninth year of Khải Định's reign), she was further honored with the title “Trinh Uyển Dực Bảo Trung Hưng Thái Dương phu nhân tôn thần.” Since then, the worship of Ba has been increasingly solidified within the community. Every year, on the 12th of the first lunar month – the main festival day, the villagers of Chiêm Sơn and nearby areas solemnly organize the Ba festival according to traditional rituals, as an indispensable part of the cultural and spiritual life of the rice-growing people here.

TRADITIONAL RITUALS IN THE CEREMONY
The ceremony of the Ba Chiem Son Festival takes place solemnly, reflecting the villagers' reverence for the goddess. The series of rituals usually begins on the evening of the 11th and lasts until the end of the 12th of the first lunar month. Typical rituals include: 
- Mộc dục Ceremony: Before the main ceremony begins, the villagers perform the Mộc dục ceremony (bathing the statue) to purify Ba's statue. The statue is bathed with water from leaves and fragrant flowers, demonstrating solemnity and respect towards the deities. This ritual opens the ceremony, preparing a sacred space to welcome Ba for the festivities.
- Túc yết Ceremony: Held on the evening of the 11th of the first lunar month. This is the ceremony of offering incense and offerings to "túc trực" and respectfully invite Ba to attend the festival. The offerings to Ba during the Túc yết ceremony include a tray of rice, fruits, and especially a grilled rice paper – a symbolic offering rich in local culture. Although simple, the Túc yết ritual is filled with sincere devotion, marking the beginning of the official ceremonial activities.
- Kỵ Bà Ceremony (Great Offering): Conducted at midnight, the moment of transition from the 11th to the 12th of the first lunar month. This is the main offering ceremony to commemorate the death anniversary of Ba Chiem Son – the most solemn peak of the ceremony. In the quiet atmosphere of the late night, the elders and reputable dignitaries of the village (after having purified themselves) wear traditional ceremonial attire to conduct the grand offering ritual. The offerings to Ba during the Kỵ ceremony include a variety of rich offerings: rice, pork, fruits, betel leaves, flowers, and especially must include a freshwater crab, a clove of garlic, a stalk of mustard greens, and a civet cat – unique offerings associated with local legends and beliefs. The sounds of gongs and drums resonate heroically in the night, combined with 20 traditional chants, praying for national peace and prosperity, favorable weather, and abundance for every household. 
- Sắc Procession: Takes place on the morning of the 12th of the first lunar month – the main festival day. From early morning, the villagers organize a solemn procession from Ben Gia on the banks of the Thu Bồn River to Dinh Bà Chiêm Sơn. Leading the procession is a lively lion dance team, followed by a team of gongs and drums, a traditional music ensemble, and then the procession of local agricultural products and the procession of the title (the royal decree from the Nguyen dynasty for Ba) carried by 16 strong young men from the village. The procession also includes honor guards and a large number of local residents and tourists participating in a respectful yet lively atmosphere. Upon arriving at Dinh Bà, the title proclamation ceremony is solemnly held to recall the merits and titles of Ba from years past. At the end of the ceremony, all offerings are shared among the villagers, and everyone partakes in the blessings right there, with the belief of receiving good fortune and peace at the beginning of the year. All rituals in the ceremony have been preserved by the Chiêm Sơn community for generations, imbued with sincere devotion and the worship of the Mother. These traditional rituals not only vividly recreate the cultural folklore but also contribute to educating future generations about gratitude to their roots and pride in their homeland's heritage.

VIBRANT FESTIVAL ACTIVITIES AND FOLK GAMES
After the solemn ceremony, the festival activities are lively and bustling, attracting a large number of residents and tourists. The festival of Ba Chiem Son features many cultural, sports, and unique folk games, creating a joyful and cheerful atmosphere throughout the countryside. During the festival days, visitors can immerse themselves in unique experiences such as: singing Bài chòi – an engaging folk art form from Quang; enjoying the countryside market with rustic culinary dishes; watching lively lion dance performances; cheering on exciting volleyball matches; and enjoying folk performances by local residents...

CULTURAL AND TOURISM SIGNIFICANCE OF THE FESTIVAL
For the people, the Ba Chiem Son Festival is not just a common religious activity, but has long become an indispensable spiritual nourishment, contributing to enriching the cultural life of the community. This is one of the most representative Mother worship festivals in Quang, where generations of local residents place their spiritual beliefs and hopes for a peaceful life and bountiful harvests. Through the festival, many precious traditional cultural values are preserved and transmitted vibrantly: from ancient offering rituals to folk songs and unique local games. The festival is also an occasion to strengthen neighborhood ties, enhance solidarity within the community, and foster pride in the heritage of their homeland among every child of Quang. In terms of heritage, the Ba Chiem Son Festival has been officially included in the List of National Intangible Cultural Heritage by the Ministry of Culture, Sports and Tourism in 2025. This recognition affirms the importance of the festival in the treasure trove of national cultural heritage, while opening up opportunities for the locality to enhance the preservation and promotion of the festival's values in the new phase.

fest_39.name: The Procession of the Chợ Được Lady's Palanquin
fest_39.description: The Chợ Được Lady Procession Festival is a celebration honoring the founder of Chợ Được in Thăng An commune, Da Nang city (previously part of Phước Ấm village, Bình Triều commune, Thăng Bình, Quảng Nam). OVERVIEW OF THE FESTIVAL The Chợ Được Lady Procession Festival usually takes place over two days, the 10th and 11th of the first lunar month each year – right after the Lunar New Year when the weather is favorable and people's hearts are filled with wishes for a peaceful new year. The main venue is the Chợ Được area and the Chợ Được Lady Shrine in Phước Ấm village, which is associated with the legend of the Lady. The festival consists of two main parts: the ceremonial part and the entertainment part, interweaving solemn rituals with folk cultural activities. The 10th of the first lunar month typically begins with preparation rituals and some opening activities, while the peak of the festival occurs on the 11th with the official procession. ORIGIN AND LEGEND OF THE CHỢ ĐƯỢC LADY According to legend, the Lady's father, named Trí, was once a high-ranking official in the Lê dynasty. Her mother, from the Trịnh family, was named Tình. The Lady was born in a dignified environment. When her mother went into labor, a whirlwind appeared outside, with dust swirling and white clouds covering the sky. When the Lady was born, she had a strong physique, was as white as snow, fragrant as flowers, walked unusually, and had a clear, resonant voice, with a body that seemed to lack bones. She practiced as a healer, curing the sick, teaching the villagers about trade, and frequently using her magical powers to deal with corrupt officials. At the age of 18, she passed away in her hometown. On the day of her passing, her spirit traveled down the Trường Giang River to Phước Ấm village (Bình Triều commune), inspiring the establishment of the bustling and prosperous Chợ Được market. In gratitude, the people of Phiếm Ái village built a tomb for her. The villagers revered her, regularly sending people to take turns guarding and caring for the tomb. One day, however, a buffalo knocked over her tomb. Immediately after, the buffalo collapsed and died for unknown reasons. Fearing her wrath, the villagers prepared offerings and invited a priest to apologize. After the ceremony, while chatting, the priest inadvertently spoke disrespectfully of her. However, as soon as he finished speaking, he suddenly felt a severe headache, and a few days later, he died unexpectedly. In the 6th year of the Thành Thái reign, the people of Phước Ấm and Chợ Được merchants submitted a petition to the government, province, and Ministry of Rituals requesting the recognition of the Chợ Được Lady as "Tề thục dực bảo trung hưng trung đẳng thần." In the 40th year of the Khải Định reign, she was honored with the title "Trang huy dực bảo trung hưng thượng đẳng thần." She was also exalted as "Tề thục dực bảo trang huy thượng đẳng thần," "Thần nữ linh ứng Nguyễn Thị Tôn Thần," etc. It is said that the Chợ Được Lady is the patroness of trade and the village's guardian spirit for the people of Phước Ấm. She established a small tea shop by the roadside, near the riverbank, attracting more and more visitors. Gradually, the quiet village transformed into a bustling market, with people from all directions coming to set up stalls and build houses, creating a lively town. The Chợ Được Lady procession prays for "national peace and people's safety," expressing the villagers' gratitude to the Chợ Được Lady – who brought a peaceful life to the village. The procession reenacts historical figures or events such as: the Two Trưng Sisters riding elephants to fight invaders, Saint Gióng driving away the An invaders, and the swift steps of the hero Nguyễn Huệ of the Tây Sơn dynasty… All of this aims to instill love for the homeland in future generations, ensuring that the Lady's contributions are remembered forever. On December 31, 2008, the Chợ Được Lady Shrine was recognized as a provincial historical site by the Quảng Nam Provincial People's Committee. On December 19, 2014, the Ministry of Culture, Sports and Tourism recognized the Chợ Được Lady procession festival as a national intangible cultural heritage. fest_40.name: The Phuong Chao Lady Festival
fest_40.description:
The Phuong Chao Festival is a unique and ancient folk festival of the people of Da Nang. The festival takes place annually on the 25th day of the 2nd lunar month at the Phuong Chao shrine in Khuong My village, Dai Cuong commune, Dai Loc district, Quang Nam province (now part of Vu Gia commune, Da Nang city). This is an occasion for local people to remember and pay tribute to the merits of Phuong Chao – the goddess revered by the people, praying for favorable weather, bountiful harvests, and a peaceful, prosperous life in their homeland. The festival also stems from the aspiration for national peace and is a testament to the spirit of community cohesion and cultural exchange among regions in Quang. With a history of hundreds of years, the Phuong Chao Festival has become an important cultural and spiritual event, deeply rooted in the tradition of "drinking water, remembering its source" of the people of Da Nang.

ORIGIN AND LEGEND OF PHUONG CHAO
Phuong Chao, also known as Ba Cho Duoc, was born Nguyen Thi Cua on February 25, 1800, in Phuong Chao village, Phiem Ai district (now part of Dai Loc commune). It is said that she was a celestial being who descended to earth; upon her birth, a good omen appeared with white clouds covering the area. Growing up, she practiced medicine to help the people and punished the wicked, earning the respect of many. She only lived on earth for 17 years before passing away, but her spirit continued to manifest and bless the good people, leading to the fishing village of Phiem Ai by the Vu Gia River becoming more populous and prosperous. In gratitude for her merits, the villagers built a shrine right in her hometown of Phuong Chao. 

The royal decree elevated Phuong Chao to the status of a high-ranking deity. The legend states that after her deification in her hometown, Phuong Chao traveled to Phuoc Am (Thang An commune), helping the people establish a market for increasingly prosperous trade; thus, the Cho Duoc market (a colloquial name meaning "buying well and selling well") was formed, closely associated with her reputation. The local people, feeling grateful, established a temple and submitted a petition to the court for her elevation. During the Nguyen dynasty, Phuong Chao was granted divine status twice by the king: the first time in the 6th year of Thanh Thai (1894), elevating her to Trung Dang deity, and in the 4th year of Khai Dinh (1919), she was further honored with the title of Thuong Dang deity. To express gratitude for her contributions, two traditional festivals associated with her name are held annually in Da Nang. In Phuoc Am village (Thang An commune), on the 11th day of the first lunar month, there is a procession for Ba Cho Duoc; while in her hometown of Khuong My (Vu Gia commune), on her birthday (25th day of the 2nd lunar month), a grand festival takes place. These two events create a sacred connection between the Phiem Ai region (where she was born) and Phuoc Am (where she manifested to help the people).

TRADITIONAL RITUALS IN THE CEREMONY
The ceremonial part of the Phuong Chao Festival is conducted solemnly, reflecting the villagers' reverence towards the deities. The series of rituals usually begins on the 24th day of the 2nd lunar month (during the festival) and extends to the 25th day of the 2nd lunar month, including many traditional rituals rich in spiritual value: 

- The Ancestral Worship Ceremony: The festival opens with a ceremony to honor the spirits, aiming to remember the deceased and pray for national peace and prosperity, hoping that the souls of the departed find peace and the land remains safe and prosperous. This ritual embodies the humanitarian spirit of "harmony between yin and yang," expressing the wish for a prosperous life for all.

- The Procession of Ba: In a solemn atmosphere, the villagers organize a procession of Ba Phuong Chao around the shrine area. The palanquin is lavishly decorated, carrying the tablet (or statue) of Ba, carried by the village elders and young men, led by flags and the sound of drums and gongs. The procession, consisting of hundreds of people, creates a majestic scene that attracts many participants.

- The Flower Lantern Release: In the evening, the locals organize a flower lantern release on the Vu Gia River next to Ba's shrine. Hundreds of flower lanterns are lit and set afloat on the water, symbolizing prayers and gratitude sent to Phuong Chao. The scene of the flickering lanterns on the river creates a sacred and poetic atmosphere for the festival.

- The Main Offering Ceremony: On the morning of the 25th day of the 2nd lunar month, the main offering ceremony is held at the shrine dedicated to Ba Phuong Chao. The offerings are prepared with care, including incense, fruits, and possibly sacrificial items depending on local customs. The officiating team consists of respected elders in the village, who recite prayers praising Ba's merits and praying for favorable weather and peace for all. A special feature of this festival is that the offering participants are selected from virtuous young women in the village – unlike many places where men usually take this role. This uniqueness stems from the legend of Ba Phuong Chao, who loved children, singing, and boat racing, so the later generations show their respect by allowing pure young women to serve in the offering ceremony. During the festival days, young women are given time off from school or work by their families and schools (if still studying) to fully participate in the offering ceremony, demonstrating their sincere respect and maintaining the village's unique customs.

VIBRANT FESTIVAL ACTIVITIES AND FOLK GAMES
Following the solemn rituals is a vibrant festival atmosphere, where tourists and locals immerse themselves in the lively cultural festival. Khuong My village during the festival days is filled with colorful flags and flowers, the sound of drums and gongs resounding, and the cheers of excitement. Many cultural, sports, and engaging folk games are organized, providing rich experiences for participants. Notable activities include traditional boat racing on the Vu Gia River, attracting many paddlers to compete; singing Bai Choi – a folk singing form characteristic of Central Vietnam, where participants sing and play games on bamboo platforms; the lively lion dance to kick off the festival; along with the activity of releasing glowing flower lanterns on the river at night and many other fun folk games (tug-of-war, swinging, blindfolded goat catching, etc.). Visitors also have the opportunity to enjoy folk art performances, watch traditional opera, and visit traditional food stalls, creating a colorful festival cultural picture that leaves a deep impression on festival-goers.

CULTURAL AND TOURISM ROLES AND VALUES OF THE FESTIVAL
For the people of Da Nang, the Phuong Chao Festival is not just a regular religious activity but has become an indispensable spiritual nourishment, playing an important role in the cultural and spiritual life of the community. This festival is closely linked to the worship of the Mother Goddess among the Vietnamese, reflecting the principle of "drinking water, remembering its source" and the sincere gratitude towards ancestors, while also expressing the aspiration for a peaceful and prosperous life, national peace, and public safety. Through the festival, many valuable traditional cultural values are preserved and passed down through generations – from traditional ceremonial rituals to folk songs and characteristic folk games – contributing to strengthening community bonds and enhancing local solidarity.

In terms of heritage, the Phuong Chao Festival was officially recognized as a national intangible cultural heritage by the Ministry of Culture, Sports, and Tourism in 2020. This recognition affirms the importance of the festival in the national cultural treasure, while also motivating the locality to continue preserving and promoting the festival's values in the new era. The government and the people view this as both a source of pride and a shared responsibility, continuously striving to preserve and enhance the festival, valuing both tangible cultural heritage (the shrine, Ba's tomb) and intangible heritage (rituals, legends, folk arts) related to it. Alongside this, the promotion and introduction of the festival are also being strengthened, aiming to make the Phuong Chao Festival a unique cultural and spiritual tourism product of Da Nang, attracting visitors from afar to experience and learn about the local cultural identity.

It can be said that the festival is both a priceless cultural heritage of the land and holds great potential for sustainable tourism development, contributing to introducing the image of Da Nang's homeland and people, rich in tradition, to friends from all over.

fest_41.name: The craft of making bamboo and coconut houses in Cam Thanh.
fest_41.description:
In Quang Nam (now Da Nang), whenever people hear the song "Stand up with coconut leaf guns / Our homeland rises up, defeating the American invaders," they think of Cam Thanh, a revolutionary base with the legendary Bay Mau Coconut Forest, which became famous for its uprising with coconut leaf guns in September 1964. The mangrove forest here not only "shelters soldiers and surrounds the enemy" but has also provided raw materials for the formation and development of the famous bamboo and coconut house-making profession over the past few hundred years, contributing to the rich cultural values of the traditional crafts of Hoi An and Da Nang. Cam Thanh, known as Thanh Chau village during the feudal period, is located in Thanh Chau commune, Hoa Vang district. This village lies to the southeast of Hoi An city (now part of Hoi An Dong Ward), about 3 km from the Hoi An Ancient Town – a UNESCO World Heritage Site, covering an area of approximately 970.42 hectares, of which more than one-third is water surface with 348.69 hectares.

NATURAL CONDITIONS AND ECOLOGICAL ENVIRONMENT
This land is surrounded by rivers and water, with the south and southwest being the lower reaches of the Thu Bon River, the east and northeast being the Ba Chươm River, and the Do River to the north and northwest. The Dinh River and Do River connect the Thu Bon River with the Ba Chươm River in a southwest-northeast direction. The numerous rivers and channels, some wide and some narrow, some shallow and some deep, wind through sandbanks and mounds along the lush, year-round green mangrove forests like Thuan Tinh (Con Kien), Con Ong Hoi, Con Tien, Con Ba Xa, Go Hi, Go Gia, creating a picturesque landscape. Perhaps due to its proximity to the sea entrance of Cua Dai, which is also the confluence of three major rivers of Quang Nam (Chien Dan, Thu Bon, Vu Gia) and the Co Co River, the ecosystem in Cam Thanh is very special, characterized by a river mouth mangrove forest with the dominant species being the nipa palm. The mangrove nipa palm ecosystem here is not only an ideal environment for many species of birds and aquatic life to thrive but also contributes to the biodiversity that led to Cu Lao Cham – Hoi An being recognized as a World Biosphere Reserve in 2009, while also creating a strategic position for coastal defense and river mouth protection.

In addition to nipa palm, bamboo is also a thriving plant in Cam Thanh village. The bamboo hedges running along the riverbanks or village paths, at the entrance or the end of gardens, not only add charm and tranquility to Cam Thanh village but also provide raw materials for creating many household items and building houses. With favorable natural conditions and geopolitical, military, and economic positions, residents have settled in Cam Thanh early on, developing the area into a prosperous land. Despite being severely devastated during the two wars against French colonialism and American imperialism, Cam Thanh boasts over 23 historical and archaeological sites recognized at national and provincial levels, such as the architectural foundations of Cham culture and the tomb of Lady Trieu Quan, the ancestral tombs of the Tran and Le clans, ancient wells, etc., along with a rich and diverse intangible cultural heritage system, including rituals, festivals, customs, culinary culture, folk arts, and traditional crafts. Notably, the profession of harvesting bird's nests in Thanh Chau has been recognized as a national intangible cultural heritage, demonstrating the historical and cultural depth of Cam Thanh in the international trading port of Faifo – Hoi An.

From the perspective of traditional crafts, besides the bird's nest harvesting profession and the once-famous boat trading profession, Cam Thanh is also renowned for its distinctive bamboo and coconut house-making craft. The Bay Mau Coconut Forest in Cam Thanh, covering an area of 106.01 hectares, is concentrated in the villages of Thanh Tam, Thanh Nhat, and Van Lang. This forest, which remains green year-round, not only protects against storms and retains silt but also provides dry coconut leaves to develop the traditional bamboo and coconut house-making profession, serving the housing needs of the local community and the recent demand for green tourism infrastructure.

During the two resistance wars against French colonialism and American imperialism, the Cam Thanh nipa palm forest became a solid revolutionary base, helping to secure the land and village, leading to glorious victories, with the September 1964 uprising being a typical example, contributing to the nation's resounding victory in the historic spring of 1975.

HISTORY OF THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE PROFESSION
According to preserved records and historical documents, in the 16th-18th centuries, taking advantage of their experience with rivers and water and being adjacent to the international trading port of Hoi An, the boat trading profession in Thanh Chau village flourished, forming a trade route along the Central Coast, even extending to the southern regions. Recognizing that the mangrove waters of the village could support the growth of nipa palms like in the south, boat owners brought seeds back to plant, gradually developing into the vast nipa palm forests we see today. In addition to bringing seeds to plant in the new land, knowledge of using nipa palm leaves for housing was also learned and adopted by boat traders. Based on the available raw materials, bamboo is used for the load-bearing frame, and nipa leaves are used for walls and roofing. With hard work and creativity, the people of Cam Thanh have expanded the bamboo and coconut house-making profession, meeting local demands and serving residents of neighboring areas; preserving the values of traditional bamboo and coconut houses while also creating new styles and products for tourism and contemporary aesthetic needs. The strong development of the bamboo and coconut house-making profession in Cam Thanh has gradually influenced and spread to other localities such as Cam Chau, Cam An, Cam Kim, etc.

RAW MATERIALS AND TOOLS
Specializing in bamboo and coconut house-making, the people of Cam Thanh have created a rich system of tools with over 40 types used in various stages of the profession, from preparing raw materials to processing the frame, leaf sheets, and assembling and finishing the house. Some tools are involved in multiple production stages. Each stage requires specific experience and techniques to create a house that is both beautiful and durable. Preparing quality bamboo and coconut materials is one of the important factors in making a sturdy and beautiful house. Due to the requirements for durability and resistance to pests, craftsmen often choose bamboo that is 4-5 years old for house construction. Bamboo harvested in January is the best because this is when the bamboo accumulates the most nutrients. After being cut, the bamboo is soaked in mud for about one to one and a half years to increase its durability and pest resistance, then taken out for processing into frames or sheets for walls, etc. People dig long holes along the riverbanks and carefully stack each bamboo pole inside, securing them with stakes, then cover them with coconut leaves and soil. According to artisans in the bamboo and coconut house-making profession, the nipa palms in Cam Thanh grow on sandy soil that is firm, slightly pink, and more durable than those grown in muddy areas, thus they are prioritized for roofing. Nipa palms planted for five years can have their leaves harvested, with two harvests each year, in March and August of the lunar calendar. People use machetes to cut the older leaves, leaving the younger leaves and buds for future harvests. Leaves harvested in March are of better quality than those in August due to the longer growth period. To facilitate cutting and efficient transportation, people usually cut from the outside towards the center of the grove. At the same time, they also trim some of the palm fronds to clear the path. Previously, these fronds were dried and used as fuel for cooking. After cutting, the nipa leaves are pulled ashore or loaded onto boats for transport to the processing stage. Depending on whether the leaves are used for roofing or walls, the nipa leaves are stripped to separate the stalks and leaves or split in half (into two parts) using skilled techniques honed over years of practice. People often choose large-leaved nipa for stripping and separating the leaves and stalks. The leaves are tied together into sheets. The stalks, leaves, and split nipa are dried and bundled, stored in a dry place. To ensure the leaves dry evenly and are convenient for processing, people usually lay the stalks and leaves in the same direction and close together, with the stalks on top and the leaves underneath, marking every 50 stalks with a sign. The drying time depends on the weather, ranging from 10 to 20 days. Bundling the nipa leaves for storage is also an art, requiring meticulous care to ensure the leaves do not break and the stalks are straight. To achieve straight bundles, people align the stalks and leaves in one direction, thread a coconut rope through the ends and tops, and tie them tightly. Dried nipa leaves can be soaked in water in a well-ventilated area for about a week, then pulled out and dried again to enhance durability and pest resistance. The stalks of nipa are used for walls, partitions, roofing, and ceilings. The nipa leaf sheets are used for roofing doors, family gatherings, making umbrellas, and raincoats. The split nipa sheets are used for roofing and walls.

PROCESS OF MAKING BAMBOO AND COCONUT HOUSES
A traditional bamboo and coconut house, whether three or five rooms, with or without eaves, consists of load-bearing frames made of bamboo (columns, beams, rafters, and crossbeams) and a covering system (roof, walls, doors made of nipa leaves) built on a raised foundation. To create a complete house, the processing of raw materials is crucial, requiring craftsmen to have a deep understanding of the structure of a traditional bamboo and coconut house, the required scale of the house, and the height of the foundation compared to the surrounding ground to select bamboo for columns, beams, and rafters, and choose nipa for roofing, walls, and doors appropriately. This not only relates to technique but also reflects the rich knowledge accumulated by craftsmen and the community over hundreds of years of practice. Bamboo soaked for the appropriate time is dried before processing the components of the house. Long, straight, and evenly sized bamboo poles are selected for crossbeams. In folk belief, the crossbeam is considered the backbone of the house, so great care is taken in choosing bamboo for it. The bamboo should be of moderate age, not too old or too young, as the saying goes, "old bamboo dies early, young bamboo dies young." The bamboo stalks must be thick and straight, without being finely shaved, and the nodes should not be broken. Sturdy, thick bamboo sections are used for beams and rafters. Bamboo used for connections, fasteners, doors, and wall panels must also be selected from strong, durable bamboo. For the house columns, fresh bamboo is not used; instead, straight, sturdy sections are preferred. In the past, craftsmen used hand saws, chisels, hand drills, and knives to meticulously perform each step with careful calculations to ensure the aesthetics and sturdiness of the house while saving materials. Nowadays, the use of mechanical tools in processing is more common, but traditional tools and techniques still play an important role. Alongside processing the load-bearing frame components, the processing of roofing, walls, family gathering areas, and doors is also carried out. Roofing sheets (panels) come in various types such as two-layer, three-layer, and four-layer panels. Depending on the size and area of the house, craftsmen select nipa sheets that are appropriately sized, usually with similar lengths. With diligence and skill, craftsmen use hand tools to weave nipa, connecting panels with bamboo fasteners using rattan (later using fishing lines) to create sturdy sheets, approximately 1 meter wide. First, the craftsman selects a flat, spacious area, then arranges the dry nipa sheets closely together with the stalks on top, uses a bamboo rod to pierce through the leaves below, and ties them together. Next, they tie the first panel and the third and fourth panels, ensuring they are spaced 25-27 cm apart to match the distance of the crossbeams for easier roofing. Depending on the width and length of the roof, more or fewer panels are prepared. Typically, each roof has 2-3 layers of panels. The walls surrounding the house can be made in various styles, such as leaf walls, mixed leaf and stalk walls, yin-yang walls, single-layer and multi-layer stalk walls, etc. Depending on the intended use, the wall panels are sized accordingly and can be made in various shapes, such as solid walls, walls with doorways or windows, or walls with ventilation openings. Components of the house, such as family gathering areas and doors, are also constructed simultaneously with the wall panels. Family gathering areas and doors have frames made of split bamboo or are fixed with bamboo fasteners, covered on the outside with layers of nipa leaves from bottom to top. Another component made from nipa leaves is the decorative panel used to cover the top of the crossbeams.

Assembling the house is a crucial step in the process of making bamboo and coconut houses in Cam Thanh. This stage requires the coordinated efforts of multiple craftsmen. To prepare for the assembly, the load-bearing frame components are transported to the designated elevated foundation. Next, craftsmen connect the beams and rafters using bamboo fasteners, then tie the beams to the crossbeams with rattan or fishing line to form the roof frame. In folk belief, the total number of crossbeams and rafters used for the roof is always an "auspicious number," with each roof having 4 or 6 beams. Furthermore, as the eastern side is considered more favorable, the crossbeams and rafters of the house roof are always placed with the base on the left. The length of the crossbeams is also chosen based on auspicious measurements according to the Lo Ban scale. The bamboo columns at the back are placed in holes about 1 meter deep. Craftsmen use bamboo ladders and columns to support the roof frame at the column tops, then use fasteners to connect the column tops to the beams. This process is repeated for the front columns. Craftsmen use a system of supports to stabilize the house frame, then adjust the height and spacing appropriately before securely burying the column bases and erecting additional main columns. If building a house with eaves, they must continue to erect the eaves frame. Once the frame is securely fixed, craftsmen begin roofing the house. Each nipa leaf sheet is pulled up and tightly tied to the crossbeams in the order of the lower layers first, then the upper layers from left to right. After that, dry nipa leaves are placed over the ridge and secured with a long bamboo pole. Next, they assemble the family gathering area, decorative panels, erect the walls, and install windows and doors. Most windows and doors of bamboo and coconut houses are designed as hinged doors. The door supports are also used to secure the door when it is closed.

CULTURAL AND SOCIAL VALUES
The formation and development of the bamboo and coconut house-making profession in Cam Thanh not only demonstrate the historical and cultural depth of the land but also reflect the ecological and natural characteristics of the area. The people of Thanh Chau, now Cam Thanh, with their creativity and skilled hands, have learned to overcome difficulties and utilize the advantages of nature to serve their lives, with the values brought by the bamboo and coconut house-making profession being vivid evidence. Although there is no specific guild or worship system, families and establishments involved in making bamboo and coconut houses actively participate in rituals for peace and prosperity for the village, praying for favorable weather and a peaceful community, and especially for the profession to continue thriving. The contributions of the bamboo and coconut house-making profession in Cam Thanh to the intangible cultural heritage of Hoi An in particular and the nation in general include a system of experiences and knowledge related to the exploitation of natural resources and cultural habitation; enriching the ethnic language through a unique terminology system of the profession. Through the practice of the profession, the community has not only accumulated many experiences to enhance work efficiency and create more durable and beautiful houses but has also increasingly innovated new products that meet the needs of the market and the times, attracting tourists to participate in experiences with enthusiasm and passion. Recognizing the value of the Cam Thanh nipa palm forest ecosystem in economic development, especially in tourism, as well as aiming to preserve and develop the traditional bamboo and coconut profession in the new context, Hoi An city has implemented many policies to protect and promote the Cam Thanh nipa palm forest ecosystem, develop community tourism based on traditional professions, especially bamboo and coconut, and train and pass on the profession. The inventory, identification, and proposal for the preservation and promotion of cultural heritage values in general and the nipa palm profession in particular in Cam Thanh have been early concerns of specialized agencies in Hoi An. The bamboo and coconut house-making profession in Cam Thanh carries the unique characteristics of Hoi An that not every place possesses. It is not only about creatively utilizing natural resources to serve life, but moreover, the essence of the profession has made significant contributions to the cultural heritage of Hoi An and the socio-economic development of the locality and the country. With appropriate policies from the local government of Hoi An and the diligence, meticulousness, and innovative thinking of the community, it is believed that the products of the bamboo and coconut house-making profession in Cam Thanh will continue to gain recognition far and wide. The bamboo and coconut house-making profession in Cam Thanh, Hoi An has been recognized as a national intangible cultural heritage. The ceremony to receive this title will take place on the evening of September 27, 2024, on the occasion of the 60th anniversary of the Cam Thanh Liberation Uprising.

fest_42.name: The profession of growing vegetables in Tra Que – Hoi An
fest_42.description:
The characteristics of the Trà Quế vegetable growing profession in Hội An are that the crops here are mainly local varieties maintained for hundreds of years. Trà Quế vegetable village in Cẩm Hà commune (now part of Hội An Tây Ward, Da Nang City) is located about 2.5 km north of the center of Hội An. This place is like a river island, surrounded by the Để Võng River and Trà Quế lagoon. When mentioning the name Trà Quế, the first association is the famous traditional vegetable growing profession that has existed for a long time, linked to the formation and development of the land.

OUTSTANDING VALUES OF TRÀ QUẾ VEGETABLE GROWING
Trà Quế is a land that was formed quite early. Archaeologists have found traces of the Sa Huỳnh culture dating back 2000 years. From the Trà Quế landmark to the Bà Yàng temple relic, ancient stone wells, etc., not only do they evoke the imprint of the Cham people in history, but many historical and cultural relics, as well as revolutionary sites of the Vietnamese people in Trà Quế, demonstrate the long-standing and continuous historical process of the local community. Many sources indicate that over 300 years ago, the first Vietnamese settlers from the Phạm, Mai, Nguyễn, and Lê clans arrived to settle in the Trà Quế area. Later, the Trần and Hồ clans also joined. Initially, the residents primarily lived by fishing in the river. During their settlement, they discovered that certain vegetables cooked with shrimp, crabs, and fish were very delicious, so they brought seeds back to plant for personal use. With their creativity and hard work, some locals thought about clearing more land to grow vegetables and rice. From there, patches of coriander, mint, then basil, onions, cabbage, and chives gradually emerged in this area. Due to being cultivated in suitable soil conditions, along with proper care techniques, the vegetables not only grew lush but also had a distinctive delicious flavor. Therefore, Trà Quế gradually became a famous vegetable village far and wide.

HISTORY OF FORMATION AND DEVELOPMENT
Historically, Trà Quế was also known as Nhự Quế, Thanh Quế, Nhà Quế. Folklore tells that around the 18th century, a king was traveling on the Đế Võng River and stopped by the village, tasting a type of vegetable that reminded him of tea in fragrance and cinnamon in spiciness, and thus named the vegetable village Trà Quế. The Thanh Hà land register established in the 17th year of Gia Long (1818) also recorded the name Trà/Nhà Quế. Thus, by the early 19th century at the latest, the name Trà Quế had appeared. In the Quảng Nam xã chí document from the École française d'Extrême-Orient, it mentions the local products of Thanh Hà village in the 1940s as follows: “Thanh Hà village has an area of over 700 acres, with about 5000 inhabitants. The specialty of this village is fresh vegetables, rice, and cassava... Except for fresh vegetables, other food products are not enough for the villagers. The main occupations of this village are tile and brick making, pottery... The village also has fishing activities but on a small scale, while agriculture occupies half of the village. Besides these specialized trades, there are also other jobs, but they are not significant.” This shows that the vegetable growing profession was almost the main occupation for economic development in the past. During the resistance against the French and Americans, Trà Quế was an important revolutionary base for the military and people of Cẩm Hà commune and Hội An town. To evade the enemy, the people of Trà Quế would produce vegetables during the day and dig tunnels to hide officials at night. The baskets of Trà Quế vegetables not only fed families but also contributed to feeding soldiers and officials; the fragrance of Trà Quế vegetables carried not only the essence of the sea, wind, sand, and the algae of Trà Quế lagoon but also the sweat, tears, and blood of the children of Trà Quế who sacrificed to protect, preserve, and build this land.

THE PERIOD AFTER 1975 TO PRESENT
After 1975, the people of Trà Quế vegetable village began the process of building and reconstructing their homeland, improving the land for growing crops to stabilize their lives and develop the economy from traditional vegetable farming. Infrastructure gradually changed, and the living standards of the people improved. By 2001, Hội An town (now Hội An city) planned to establish concentrated vegetable production with a total area of 15 hectares. Currently, Trà Quế vegetable village has 207 households specializing in vegetable cultivation with 345 workers. The area of land for vegetable cultivation has been improved to 18 hectares. In 2018, vegetable yield reached 792 tons, with a value of 10.73 billion VND, and the average income of vegetable growers and service providers was about 4.4 million VND per person per month. According to statistics, Trà Quế vegetable village has about 55 types of vegetables, including some that have lost their varieties like aromatic onions, lettuce, and long mint. The remaining types of vegetables are well-maintained and their quality is continuously improved.

CULTIVATION TECHNIQUES AND FOLK KNOWLEDGE
In addition to preserving traditional cultivation methods in the vegetable growing process from selecting and preserving seeds to planting, caring, harvesting, and consuming, the residents have accumulated experience and adjusted methods to produce high-quality, safe vegetables that require less production time. Folk knowledge accumulated over time reflects the meticulousness and diligence of hardworking farmers who invest their passion into every patch of vegetables. This experience is not exclusive to anyone but is a collective resonance of the entire community to create the most common production methods, which not all craft villages possess in such harmony. Over generations, thanks to the soil conditions and appropriate cultivation and care techniques, especially the green manure from algae in the Trà Quế lagoon and Để Võng River, the vegetables here have a unique deliciousness. Each type of vegetable has its own shape and flavor. The shape and size of the vegetables are also different from those in other places, such as small, thick leaves, sturdy low plants, particularly fragrant, and richer in taste; soft vegetables that seem to melt in the mouth without being chewy. When mixed together, the vegetables create a blend of five flavors: spicy, sweet, bitter, sour, and astringent, and to create delicious dishes, locals often select suitable vegetables and adjust the quantity as desired. Trà Quế has distinctive vegetables that one cannot miss tasting, such as mint, basil, young cabbage, and chives. The vegetables in Trà Quế are not only daily meals in family dinners but also essential ingredients that enhance the flavor of local specialties like tam hữu, ram cuốn, mì Quảng, cao lầu, bánh xèo, etc., but they are also folk remedies that can treat colds, flu, rashes, and many other seasonal ailments.

LOCAL PLANT VARIETIES AND CONSERVATION EFFORTS
Another outstanding feature of Trà Quế vegetables is that the plant varieties here are primarily local varieties maintained for hundreds of years. The seeds here, especially those for planting, have small, firm seeds, while the varieties grown from branches have sturdy, small stems that are very fragrant. The locals always focus on preserving traditional varieties due to their superior qualities, delicious flavors, suitability for the soil, resistance to pests, and stable yields. Protecting traditional plant varieties is not a simple task; it is a long process tied to the profession, along with good cultivation practices to maintain a long-term seed source. After reviewing and evaluating the documentation, on April 4, 2022, the Ministry of Culture, Sports and Tourism issued Decision No. 784/QĐ-BNHTTDL announcing the List of National Intangible Cultural Heritage, which includes the Trà Quế vegetable growing profession in Cẩm Hà commune, Hội An city, Quảng Nam province, in the category of Folk Knowledge and Traditional Crafts.
