fest_43.name: Kim Bồng Woodworking – Hoi An
fest_43.description:
Kim Bồng Woodworking – Hoi An has historically, culturally, and scientifically significant values for the formation and development of the Hoi An trading port city. The Kim Bồng village, formerly known as Kim Bồng district, belonged to Mỹ Khê commune, Duy Xuyên district, mostly located in Cẩm Kim commune, Hoi An city, Quang Nam province (now part of Hoi An Ward, Da Nang City). This village was established quite early in the Hoi An trading port city during the Nguyễn lords' reign.

HISTORY OF FORMATION AND DEVELOPMENT According to oral traditions passed down by descendants of the Nguyễn, Phan, Huỳnh, and Trương clans in Cẩm Kim commune, the founding ancestor of the Kim Bồng woodworking profession was originally from Thanh Hoá, who migrated and settled here in the 16th century. Recognizing that the Kim Bồng area was bordered by rivers on three sides, located next to the large Thu Bồn river and adjacent to the international trading port city of Hoi An, it was very convenient for the development of both construction woodworking and household woodworking. The early settlers of Kim Bồng chose this place as a long-term residence to establish a traditional woodworking village. They began their craft with traditional thatched and bamboo houses, then progressed to the typical wooden frame houses known as “Tam gian nhị hạ,” and later to household furniture and transportation means (boats – small boats, and canoes).

By the late 16th to 17th centuries, Hoi An, with many favorable factors, quickly prospered, becoming an important foreign trading port city in the Đàng Trong region, leading to the development of many industries, including Kim Bồng woodworking. The urbanization process led to labor specialization and division in Hoi An. Traditional crafts flourished to meet the demands of urban life, including Kim Bồng woodworking. From here, Kim Bồng woodworking had the opportunity to develop to serve the construction needs of urban architecture, religious and spiritual structures, household wooden products, and boat building, including large cargo ships (ghe bầu).

Throughout its development, Kim Bồng woodworking has branched into four main categories: construction woodworking, household woodworking, artistic woodworking, and boat building. Among them, Trung Châu and Phước Thắng villages specialize in producing artistic and construction wood products; Đông Hà and Ngọc Thành villages lean towards boat building; Trung Hà and Vĩnh Thành villages are where household wooden products are produced. According to the recollections of the village elders, some Kim Bồng carpenters have traveled to many other localities to practice their craft. Notably, many carpenters from the village were recruited by the Nguyễn dynasty to Huế to construct palaces and tombs for the kings, receiving titles and ranks such as Bát phẩm, Cửu phẩm… or like Mr. Huỳnh Kim Hơn, who participated in building Hồ Chí Minh's tomb.

During their creative labor, Kim Bồng artisans have crafted a diverse and rich array of wooden products, including artistic wooden products (over 50 types of household artistic wood products; more than 47 types of religious and spiritual artistic wood products); household wooden products (cabinets, tables, chairs, beds, shelves, chests, boxes, trays, platters…); construction wooden products (houses, clan houses, communal houses, pagodas); and boat wooden products (canoes, boats, ships, ghe). Generally, Kim Bồng wooden products are primarily consumed in domestic markets such as Da Nang, Ho Chi Minh City, Hanoi, and Bình Định… Among them, some artistic wooden products are exported to markets in European countries, North America, and Australia.

CULTURAL SPACE AND CRAFT SPIRIT Along with the process of settling and living, the residents of Kim Bồng have established places of worship for their ancestors and the founding masters of the craft. The Kim Bồng ancestral house was built to express the sentiment of “drinking water, remembering its source,” and “eating fruit, remembering the one who planted the tree” of the Kim Bồng people. Additionally, the descendants of Kim Bồng have built clan houses and residences for living and worship. The worship space and rituals of Kim Bồng woodworking are very rich and diverse. Among them, worshiping the craft's ancestors is a common practice among many families. Kim Bồng carpenters do not identify a specific ancestor for their craft; they worship the common woodworking ancestors, such as Lỗ Ban and Lỗ Bốc, while also venerating the ancestor of all crafts, Cửu Thiên Huyền Nữ or Mr. Tiên Sư. Furthermore, all woodworking houses have a worship altar for the craft's ancestors placed in a prominent position in the house. Every year, on the 6th day of the Lunar New Year, Kim Bồng carpenters hold a ceremony to commemorate their craft's ancestors at the Kim Bồng ancestral house. The ceremony on the 6th day of the Lunar New Year is also considered the opening day for new woodworking teams.

In recent years, the Kim Bồng woodworking profession has gradually been restored and developed, contributing to improving the living standards and creating jobs for local people, thereby increasing revenue for the non-smoke industry of Cẩm Kim commune in particular and Hoi An city in general. Alongside promoting the creativity of a team of experienced artisans, many young craftsmen have been trained to inherit and maintain the activity of woodworking in the future. Currently, tourism activities in Hoi An are developing strongly, positively impacting the production and consumption of products from the village, thereby contributing to the gradual revival of the woodworking profession.

VALUE AND CONTRIBUTIONS OF KIM BỒNG WOODWORKING It can be said that Kim Bồng woodworking holds significant historical, cultural, and scientific values for the formation and development of the Hoi An trading port city. Historical value: The woodworking profession formed and developed quite early in history, not only in Hoi An but throughout the Đàng Trong region. Kim Bồng woodworking has played a crucial role in constructing urban architecture, clan houses, communal houses, pagodas, and temples in Hoi An and many other rural areas in Da Nang. Many Kim Bồng carpenters participated in building the imperial city and tombs in Huế, as well as in constructing Hồ Chí Minh's tomb. Notably, the formation and development of Kim Bồng woodworking is one of the important foundations that define the historical formation of villages in Hoi An specifically and Da Nang generally.

Cultural value: Over more than three hundred years of existence, Kim Bồng woodworking has formed a team of highly skilled craftsmen who possess knowledge, techniques, skills, and professional experience, nurturing and promoting the young workforce. Particularly, many artisans from the village have been honored as master craftsmen during the feudal period and recognized as outstanding artisans and people’s artisans in modern times. Currently, this group is responsible for teaching skills and experiences to young craftsmen, enabling them to become skilled workers contributing to the preservation and promotion of cultural values in Hoi An. Kim Bồng carpenters, with their talent, intellect, dexterous hands, and hardworking, patient nature, have left us with exquisite artistic works not only in Hoi An but also in several other provinces/cities across the country. The Kim Bồng carpenters, with their traditional carving skills in relief, intaglio, pierced carving, and multi-layered carving, have depicted smooth shapes, graceful curves, and vibrant patterns and motifs that are incredibly unique and rich in tradition, embodying the distinct identity of Kim Bồng woodworking that cannot be found elsewhere.

Through the process of integration, absorption, and selective assimilation of external cultural elements, the interaction and fusion between Hoi An and cultures in Southeast Asia, Asia, and Western countries have made Hoi An a convergence point of many different artistic styles, thereby creating the Hoi An style thanks to many generations of Kim Bồng woodworking artisans. In the current trend of renewal and integration, Kim Bồng woodworking has favorable conditions for development, affirming its position and contributing to the preservation and promotion of local and national historical and cultural values.

Scientific value: In addition to historical and cultural values, Kim Bồng woodworking is the subject of research for many scientific fields related to architecture, fine arts, history, and ethnology. From here, many articles and research projects on Kim Bồng woodworking have emerged, providing valuable scientific information contributing to the preservation, retention, and promotion of a traditional craft of Cẩm Kim in particular and Hoi An in general. With its outstanding values, Kim Bồng woodworking has been recognized by the state as an exemplary intangible cultural heritage of the nation in Decision No. 4036/QĐ-BVHTTDL dated November 21, 2016, by the Ministry of Culture, Sports, and Tourism.

fest_44.name: Thanh Châu Bird's Nest Harvesting Profession – Hoi An
fest_44.description: For the profession of harvesting bird's nests in Thanh Châu – Hội An, the cultural space related to it must first mention Thanh Châu village, also known as Yến village... HISTORY OF FORMATION AND DEVELOPMENT Located to the east of Hội An city, Thanh Châu is one of the earliest established villages in Hội An and has played a very important role in the historical and cultural development of Hội An. According to research findings, Thanh Châu village was established in the 17th century by six founding clans: Trần, Hồ, Lê, Nguyễn, Phạm, and Huỳnh. At that time, Thanh Châu village included Võng Nhi village – a village that, according to the gravestone inscription of the Trần Văn clan still present in Võng Nhi hamlet, Cẩm Thanh commune, was formed during the reign of Kinh Thống in the year of the Horse (1498). Over the course of its development, Thanh Châu village was divided into Thanh Đông, Thanh Tây, and Thanh Nam villages. Later, before 1945, Thanh Đông village was further divided into Thanh Đông, Thanh Nhứt, Thanh Nhì, and Thanh Tam. Inheriting the cultural traditions of the Vietnamese people in the North and adapting to the ecological and social conditions of the new land, the residents of Thanh Châu village engaged in various occupations such as farming, fishing, and trading by boat, especially the profession of harvesting bird's nests and processing bird's nests (yến sào) – a product that topped the "eight delicacies" of the feudal kings. Several local legends relate to the discovery and harvesting of bird's nests in Cù Lao Chàm by the residents of Thanh Châu. One legend suggests that the profession of harvesting bird's nests in Thanh Châu was initiated by a couple, Mr. Trần Tiến and his wife, who were fishermen and accidentally discovered it during a storm that washed them ashore on an island. Another legend, called Nàng Yến, explains the nesting behavior of the swallows, relating it to a girl who transformed herself to save her father from starvation by using her saliva to create a dish, which is the bird's nest of today. However, according to some historical documents, before the 13th century, the Chinese were already aware of the value of bird's nests, and some Southeast Asian countries, including the Champa people, had known how to exploit this resource. Therefore, in essence, the Vietnamese/Thanh Châu villagers learned the experience of harvesting bird's nests from the Champa people during their southward expansion. During the Nguyễn lords and the Nguyễn dynasty, the harvesting of bird's nests by the residents of Thanh Châu gradually became organized in a systematic way, evolving from spontaneous to professional, expanding from a narrow scope to the entire Central region. Through some Hán Nôm documents currently preserved in the families of the Trần and Hồ clans in Cẩm Thanh, as well as some related gravestone inscriptions, it is known that historically, the two clans Trần and Hồ in Thanh Châu village played a major role in the profession of harvesting bird's nests. PRODUCTION/ HARVESTING PROCESS Since 1975, the harvesting, processing, and consumption of bird's nests in Hội An have received attention and management support from the People's Committee of Hội An city. On December 20, 1975, the People's Committee of Hội An Town (now Hội An city) issued a decision to establish the Hội An Bird's Nest Management and Harvesting Team based on the bird's nest harvesting team of the Thanh Châu village community. Since 1975, the People's Committee of Hội An city has invested in new equipment and applied many appropriate measures to help harvest and protect bird's nests safely and effectively, gradually increasing the quantity and quality of bird's nests as well as maintaining a stable output for the products to create a sustainable and continuous source of income for the community and develop the local economy. For the profession of harvesting bird's nests in Thanh Châu, the related cultural space must first mention Thanh Châu village, also known as Yến village – the first and only village in Hội An historically associated with the profession of harvesting bird's nests. To this day, the area of Yến village in Cẩm Thanh still retains the rural village space with its characteristic roads, hamlets, and houses. The harvesting area is located on several islands in Cù Lao Chàm, about 15 km from the mainland, such as Khô cave on Khô Mẹ island; Xanh Rêu cave, Bắc Cầu cave, Kỳ Trâu cave, Cạn cave on Tai island; Tò Vò cave, Cả cave, Cột Buồm cave, Trán Quỷ cave on Lao island. To this day, the area of Yến village in Cẩm Thanh still retains the rural village space with its characteristic roads, hamlets, and houses. The harvesting area is located on several islands in Cù Lao Chàm, about 15 km from the mainland, such as Khô cave on Khô Mẹ island; Xanh Rêu cave, Bắc Cầu cave, Kỳ Trâu cave, Cạn cave on Tai island; Tò Vò cave, Cả cave, Cột Buồm cave, Trán Quỷ cave on Lao island. TYPICAL PRODUCTS With the experience, knowledge, customs, and taboos during the practice, along with the tools and means to harvest bird's nests, and especially the natural gift of bird's nests, the profession of harvesting bird's nests in Thanh Châu has created a truly distinctive and valuable bird's nest product for Hội An. It is precisely because of the outstanding historical, cultural, scientific, and economic values of this profession that on November 21, 2016, the Ministry of Culture, Sports and Tourism issued decision number 4036/QĐ – BVHTTDL to recognize the profession of harvesting bird's nests in Thanh Châu as part of the National Intangible Cultural Heritage, alongside the Kim Bồng woodworking profession in Cẩm Kim. fest_45.name: Thanh Ha Pottery Village – Hoi An
fest_45.description:
Thanh Ha Pottery Village is now located in Hoi An Tay Ward, Da Nang City (before 1945 it was part of Thanh Ha Commune, Dien Phuoc District, Dien Ban Prefecture, Quang Nam Province). 

GENERAL INTRODUCTION TO THANH HA POTTERY VILLAGE  
Thanh Ha Pottery Village is now located in Hoi An Tay Ward, Da Nang City (before 1945 it was part of Thanh Ha Commune, Dien Phuoc District, Dien Ban Prefecture, Quang Nam Province). The village has a production space for pottery, ceramics, bricks, yin-yang tiles, and lime distributed across various hamlets in the western and southern parts of the village such as: Nam Dieu, Thanh Chiếm, An Bang, Hoa Yen, Hau Xa. The pottery production area is concentrated in Nam Dieu Block, Thanh Ha Ward, Hoi An City. 

HISTORY OF FORMATION AND DEVELOPMENT  
Scale and development history  
According to the memories of the elders, about 70 years ago, there were up to 50 households producing pottery in Nam Dieu hamlet, with 30-40 potter's wheels, 8 ceramic kilns, and dozens of pottery trading households, totaling 200-300 workers. Additionally, there were some households engaged in pottery, ceramics, bricks, tiles, and lime production in Thanh Chiếm hamlet (now Thanh Chiếm Block, adjacent to Nam Dieu to the northeast), An Bang hamlet (now An Bang Block, adjacent to Nam Dieu to the north), and Hau Xa hamlet (about 1 km east of Nam Dieu). 

CULTURAL SPACE AND PRODUCTION CONDITIONS  
Current pottery situation  
Currently, Thanh Ha has 32 households engaged in pottery with 134 workers out of a total of 320 households, including 5 households producing traditional pottery, 13 households making blown glass, while the rest are engaged in decorative pottery, with at least 3 professional pottery traders; there are 4 traditional pottery kilns (up kilns, bowl kilns), 4 up kilns for firing decorative pottery, and 5 up kilns for firing blown glass. The pottery craftsmen in Thanh Ha today are all descendants of the founding clans of Thanh Ha village: Nguyen Viet, Nguyen Van, Nguy, Bui, Pham, Le. 

Pottery raw materials  
The main raw material for pottery is high-plasticity yellow clay with a high degree of adhesion. This type of clay is usually found in fields along the river, at a depth of about 50-100 cm from the field surface. Sixty years ago, the clay was mined in An Bang, Thanh Chiếm (Thanh Ha) and the land adjacent to Thanh Ha in present-day Dien Phuong. Currently, potters buy clay from Thanh Quýt (Dien Ban), Thi Lai (Duy Xuyen)… with sellers transporting the clay by boat to Thanh Ha for sale. 

PRODUCTION/EXTRACTION PROCESS  
Traditional pottery products are made according to traditional production processes as follows:  
Crafting steps:  
+ Making clay: Clay is mixed with water and then chopped and kneaded three times to make it clean and pliable.  
+ Shaping pottery (forming the body): The potter spins the wheel and shapes the clay on the wheel, with the potter sitting beside the wheel, placing the clay on the wheel, using both hands to shape it into a body.  
+ Drying: The body is sun-dried until it hardens, then adjusted for balance before being dried completely.  
+ Glazing technique (used for tiles): Glaze is made from copper, lead, red stone, kaolin… The materials are finely ground, mixed with 50% clean water to create a raw glaze, or in other words, to form a thin layer of glass to make the pottery shiny and protect it from water absorption. The lightly fired pottery is taken out, dipped in glaze, and then fired again to mature the glaze and adhere it to the pottery body.  
+ Firing pottery: Pottery and ceramics are fired in bowl kilns, with ceramic kilns referred to as green kilns, and red kilns used for firing pottery. The green kiln is rectangular, with brick walls and a clay dome roof; it is about 3m high, 5-6m wide, and 4-5m long, with 2 fire doors at the front (wood-fired), 3 ventilation doors at the back, and 3 vents in the roof. The red kiln is smaller than the green kiln, about 2.3m high, 2m wide, and 3m long. Traditional firing wood includes various types of forest wood; today, kiln workers use willow wood. Each firing batch requires 10m3 of wood for ceramics and 5-7m3 for pottery. The firing process follows these steps: warming the kiln, creating a strong fire to turn the raw materials into finished products. When firing, the kiln worker can gauge the temperature of the kiln and whether the pottery is finished by observing the smoke escaping. Previously, when firing ceramics, the worker also used a probe to check the state of the pottery inside the kiln; if the probe withstands the heat from the kiln and matures, the products inside are considered done, and the state of the probe indicates whether the products are good or bad. There are many specific names in the craft related to the state/color of the probe to describe and accompany the knowledge of product recognition. 

TYPICAL PRODUCTS  
Traditional pottery products are made according to traditional production processes as follows:  
+ Traditional Thanh Ha pottery: diverse in types (over 40 types of products), including household items (jars, lime pots, vases, pots, jars, bowls, etc.) used for storing water, salt, fish sauce, rice, grains, and local products…; production tools for weaving in Duy Xuyen, Dien Ban, and road construction in Dai Loc – Quang Nam (now Da Nang) (tubs for silk, containers for weaving threads, tools for filtering sugar); fired bricks and tiles, pottery used in religious activities (incense burners, statues of the Kitchen Gods, urns…). The characteristic shape of the products includes jars with flared mouths, narrow necks, shoulders, and tapered bottoms; pots, clay pots, and ceramic kettles share a similar flared mouth, round lip, short neck, and bulging belly with a round bottom. Unglazed pottery and ceramics have a rough or unglazed surface, fine texture, mostly without patterns, except for a few types of earthenware jars decorated with raised serrated edges and wavy patterns on the neck and shoulders.  
+ Decorative pottery: crafted more elaborately, to achieve a fine pottery surface, potters refine, settle, and filter the clay into a fine solution before pouring it into molds for 12 hours to allow the clay to precipitate, then dry the body. The decorative designs of decorative pottery often feature Chinese characters with auspicious meanings, geometric patterns, and business names… Some products are coated with a layer of pottery made from eggshells. Decorative pottery bodies can be fired in bowl kilns or separately in up kilns. Decorative pottery includes at least 33 types of products such as Buddha statues, Christ figures, wall-mounted lamps, balusters, pots, vases, architectural models, boxes, ashtrays, ceramic masks… These products are ordered by many tourism and service establishments (restaurants, hotels, cafes) in Hoi An, Da Nang, Hue, Da Lat, Ho Chi Minh City for interior and exterior decoration. In recent years, some products have been exported to Japan, Australia, Germany, the UK, France, the USA,…  
+ Blown glass – souvenir products: Blown glass is a new pottery form that emerged in the late 1990s, simply crafted but still reflecting traditional cultural themes such as the 12 zodiac animals, blown glass figures of children herding buffalo… which are popular souvenirs among tourists.  
+ Making yin-yang tiles: Yin-yang tiles are made from yellow clay like that used for pottery and go through several steps: kneading clay, molding, sun-drying, shaping (arranging in rows, tapping to curve into tiles), stacking (arranging in separate rows), sun-drying, and firing in the kiln. Yin-yang tiles are fired in bowl kilns (ceramic and pottery kilns) or up kilns, with various sizes.  
+ Making brick tiles: The steps are similar to making yin-yang tiles, differing only in the use of molds and not going through the shaping process.  
+ Making Kitchen God statues: Making mature clay, kneading, hand-molding, drying for 2 sunny days, and firing.  
+ Ceramic urns are also a religious product (used for the reburial of the deceased) crafted by making mature clay, kneading, hand-building (piece by piece), assembling, drying, and firing. 

Thanh Ha Pottery Village was recognized as a provincial-level craft village in 2014, and in 2019, Thanh Ha pottery was included in the National Intangible Cultural Heritage list by the Ministry of Culture, Sports and Tourism in Decision No. 2695/QĐ-BVHTTDL, dated August 27.

fest_46.name: Hát bả trạo
fest_46.description:
Bả Trạo Singing is a form of integrated art, a unique ritual performance associated with the Fishermen's Festival and the worship of the Whale God by the fishermen of Da Nang city. Throughout its existence and development, through the process of labor and production, the coastal residents of Da Nang have created intangible cultural values filled with "marine essence" that are always suitable for various natural conditions and social environments, in which Bả Trạo Singing becomes a tool, and the Fishermen's Festival becomes a place for people to express these unique cultural values. 

BẢ TRẠO SINGING – FOLK ART DEEPLY ROOTED IN MARITIME BELIEFS 

As the name suggests, "Bả" means to hold firmly, while "Trạo" refers to a paddle. Therefore, "Bả Trạo Singing" is understood as singing while firmly paddling, combining the singing with the rhythmic paddling movements. Not only is it a form of folk activity, but Bả Trạo Singing is also an integrated art form that skillfully combines folk dance, traditional opera, folk songs, and traditional rituals. This is also a ritual rich in spiritual elements – maritime beliefs, reflecting the worldview and life perspective of the coastal residents of Central Vietnam, especially the worship of the Whale God – the sacred sea deity regarded as the protector of fishermen during their voyages. The content of Bả Trạo Singing praises the merits of the Whale God, honors the abundance and generosity of the sea, while vividly depicting the arduous labor process at sea. In each drumbeat and folk song, listeners can feel the sincere aspiration for a prosperous and happy life, along with the courageous, optimistic, and united spirit of the coastal people, always looking towards peaceful seas and prosperous lives. 

A Bả Trạo Singing team typically includes: the lead singer standing at the front of the boat, the navigator, holding a pair of wooden clappers to lead the Bả Trạo performance from start to finish; the cabin leader standing in the boat's cabin, guarding when the boat is anchored, holding a fishing rod and a bucket; and the rear leader standing at the back of the boat, holding the paddles to steer the boat in the right direction. Along with about 10 to 16 "paddlers" depending on the locality, this number is always kept even, reflecting the balance and harmony in the fishermen's beliefs.

DISTINCTIVE VALUES 

From the perspective of folk art, Bả Trạo Singing is a valuable resource on the customs, practices, and performance arts of the coastal residents of Central Vietnam. Each lyric, dance, and drumbeat embodies the spirit of optimism, love for the profession, love for the sea, and faith in a prosperous and peaceful life. The lyrics in Bả Trạo Singing carry profound philosophical meanings and high humanitarian values – like "cultural oaths in song" passed down from generation to generation. It conveys the moral of "remembering the source of the water we drink," gratitude towards nature, and the spirit of solidarity and resilience of the coastal people. Therefore, Bả Trạo Singing is not only a musical heritage but also a spiritual heritage that needs to be preserved, protected, and promoted as an important part of the cultural life of Da Nang today.

EXPERIENCE ACTIVITIES 

Today, alongside the traditional Fishermen's Festival, Bả Trạo Singing is also performed at many cultural events and tourism festivals in Da Nang city. This folk art is also included in performance programs for tourists at various cultural spaces and art performance stages throughout the city. Particularly, some travel companies have organized Bả Trạo Singing experience activities for tourists – where participants can learn basic movements and melodies and perform right on tourist boats amidst the river and water scenery. This unique experience helps tourists gain a deeper understanding of the spiritual life and maritime culture of the fishermen of Da Nang city, while also spreading the values of folk heritage closer to the international community. Bả Trạo Singing was recognized by the Ministry of Culture, Sports and Tourism as a National Intangible Cultural Heritage under Decision No. 3084/QĐ-BVHTTDL dated September 9, 2013.

fest_47.name: Tuong Art
fest_47.description:
Tuong (or Hat Boi) is a unique traditional theatrical form rich in identity in Vietnam, considered one of the "national souls and quintessence" of the national culture. Through a process of accumulation, selection, and supplementation, along with the artistic creativity of the people and a unique system of folk culture, Tuong has woven itself into the lives of the people of Da Nang, appearing everywhere from rural areas to urban centers in cultural activities, festivals, or important events, eventually evolving into a performance art in ticketed theaters, becoming a beloved and popular spiritual dish among the local population.

HISTORY OF FORMATION AND DEVELOPMENT  
The art of Tuong in Quang has appeared very early, around the early 17th century. Following the migration of settlers to the south, Tuong accompanied them to the new land and quickly integrated into local cultural life. By the early 19th century, many Tuong troupes were formed in Da Nang, notably the Duc Giao troupe (now in Que Son commune) and the Khanh Tho troupe (in Chien Dan commune). During this period, Tuong was mainly performed in communal yards and private homes, moving through villages to serve the people. By the early 20th century, the art of Tuong in Quang entered a period of brilliant development. A series of theaters and Tuong schools emerged: Chu Chau Theater, Vinh Dien Tuong School, Bau Toa Tuong School; Tuong stages at Mieu Bong, Cho Moi, Nam O… This glorious period marked the transformation of Quang Tuong from a form of folk theater and worship to urban entertainment theater. Quang Tuong during this time had its own distinct identity, not mixed with others, while still strongly interacting with other regions.

When mentioning Quang Tuong, one cannot forget Nguyen Hien Dinh (1853-1926), who made significant contributions to establishing a distinctive Tuong style of Quang. He gathered artisans, opened theaters, prepared costumes, props, and composed many Tuong scripts. The scripts written by Nguyen Hien Dinh have become models, highly regarded by the Tuong community nationwide and are still regularly staged today.

CHARACTERISTICS OF QUANG TUONG  
The art of Quang Tuong draws from historical or legendary stories, emphasizing the heroic and tragic aspects, thus carrying a grand tone in the examples of loyalty to the country, self-sacrifice for the greater good, lessons on human behavior regarding ethics, human character, and community values, within families and towards the homeland. Each performance also reflects cultural and historical marks, the process of labor and production, containing values rich in humanity, dreams, and aspirations of the people of Da Nang. The structure of Tuong scripts is quite tight, following a chapter format: usually consisting of 3 acts (opening – conflict – climax & conclusion), sometimes 4 acts depending on the complexity of the story. Tuong characters are classified by roles such as sinh (male lead), dao (female role), lao (old man), ninh (treacherous minister), trung than (loyal minister), generals, and yeu tinh (monsters)… Each character has a distinctive personality and often represents a quality (loyal – treacherous, good – evil, brave – cowardly…). The system of melodies in Quang Tuong is very rich, but there are three main groups: speaking style (singing without rhythm), male singing, and guest singing, alongside many other melodies like xuan, ai, oan, ngam,… to express the character's emotions in each situation. The accompanying orchestra usually includes battle drums, ceremonial drums, two-stringed instruments (dan co), horn (tuong horn), nao bat, wooden fish, thanh la, along with other ethnic musical instruments. Dance in Tuong is the main means to depict the character's personality and emotions. Quang Tuong dance is highly stylized, distilled from daily activities and labor movements, absorbing the essence of folk dance forms, religious dance in ceremonies and festivals. Unlike Tuong in other regions, the distinctive style of Quang Tuong emphasizes the literary aspect, values the lyrics, and internal acting, thus often featuring less dance, with gentle and fluid movements, reflecting the lyrical and profound nature of the people of Da Nang. In the process of recreating life, Quang Tuong does not tend to be realistic but focuses on portraying the spirit to align with the spiritual life of the local people; therefore, costumes and makeup are exaggerated and stylized according to specific rules but remain relatable and easy to understand. When watching, the audience is drawn in and participates in the imagination and creativity of the performers. Through each brushstroke, each color on the face and costume, the audience will immediately understand whether the character is loyal or treacherous, good or evil.

EXPERIENCE ACTIVITIES  
When visiting Da Nang, tourists have many opportunities to enjoy Tuong art – from theater stages to street spaces or interactive experience programs. Especially during the early spring in traditional festivals, the sound of Tuong drums resonates everywhere, bringing a joyful and sacred atmosphere. Immersing in that space, watching a snippet of classical Tuong with the locals is a unique cultural experience that helps tourists feel more deeply the beauty of the soul and the rich spiritual life of the local people. The Nguyen Hien Dinh Tuong Theater is the cradle of professional Tuong in Da Nang and is a must-visit destination for those who love exploring ethnic art. Located at 155 Phan Chau Trinh, Hai Chau District, it offers tourists a unique experience with the lively sound of festival drums, classic Tuong excerpts, a performance of ethnic musical instruments, and opportunities to interact and take photos with artists in traditional costumes. The exhibition space for Tuong art within the theater grounds showcases images, costumes, masks, crowns, and exquisite armor, helping visitors understand more about the beauty of Quang Tuong art. In the ancient town of Hoi An, Tuong excerpts are performed for tourists at the Hoi An Traditional Art Performance Theater (66 Bach Dang Street), presented during the Hoi An Ancient Town Night (14th of the lunar month), during the Mid-Autumn Festival, Lunar New Year, or cultural-tourism exchange events… Besides watching performances, tourists can also transform into artisans through the activity of painting Tuong masks. In the unique artistic space named “Time Masks” by artisan Bui Quy Phong – who has been dedicated to the traditional paper mache mask-making profession for over 40 years. Not only entertainment, but Quang Tuong also carries profound humanitarian values, contributing to nurturing the soul, community feelings, and national cultural identity. The art of Quang Tuong has been recognized by the Ministry of Culture, Sports, and Tourism as a national intangible cultural heritage according to decision number: 1877/QĐ-BVHTTDL, dated June 8, 2015.

fest_48.name: Cham art performance at My Son Sanctuary
fest_48.description: Visiting the My Son Sanctuary, tourists can not only admire the ancient moss-covered architectural works but also immerse themselves in the unique artistic space of the Cham people – where sound, light, and movement blend into a vibrant cultural tapestry. CHAM ART – A BRIGHT HERITAGE OF THE CHAMPA CIVILIZATION Cham art is a treasure trove of distinctive culture that has formed and developed alongside the ancient Champa civilization – one of the most brilliant civilizations in Central Vietnam. From music, dance, to Cham rituals and festivals, all reflect a harmonious worldview between humans and nature, between earthly life and the spiritual world. Cham music and dance are deeply ceremonial, expressing reverence for the deities while celebrating the beauty of life and humanity. In the sound of the Paranưng drum and the Saranai horn, the Apsara dances, offering dances, and water-carrying dances are vividly and gracefully recreated, embodying a sacred essence. Each movement of the hands, gaze, or step contains the spirit of pride, faith, and aspiration of the Cham people through generations. Today, Cham art is not only a valuable intangible cultural heritage but also a bridge that brings tourists closer to the history and soul of the Central region – where ancient towers, music, and dance tell the story of an immortal civilization. EXPERIENCING CHAM ART AT MY SON SANCTUARY This is an intangible cultural activity vividly recreated at My Son Sanctuary. Excerpts from Cham festivals, court dances, and religious dances are staged to help those who visit My Son better appreciate the unique values of the intangible Cham culture. Cham art performance programs are regularly held at the Cham folk art performance house within the sanctuary and right at the foot of the ancient tower, allowing visitors to enjoy the performances while feeling the sacred atmosphere of the heritage. Every day, Cham artisans tell the story of their homeland through each drumbeat and dance, so that visitors not only "watch" but also "feel" the breath of the brilliant Champa civilization. SOME REPRESENTATIVE PERFORMANCES Apsara Dance: According to Cham cultural researchers, this dance serves the deities. Apsara transforms from stone into graceful, flowing dances that praise the beauty and exquisite curves that nature has bestowed upon women. The dances are performed slowly, gently, and gracefully. They are mainly expressed through hand movements, each carrying a specific meaning. When the arms are placed horizontally across the chest, it signifies happiness; when the left hand is directed back, and the right hand is clenched in front of the chest with three fingers pointing up, the index finger touching the thumb, this symbolizes the image of the Naga snake in Cham culture. Offering Dance: The Cham offering dance is a sacred ritual during festivals such as Katê, Rija Nưgar, and Rija Praung. This dance is usually performed by young girls, who balance offerings like fruits, water, or ceramic jars on their heads, holding fans or scarves, with graceful movements to show respect for the deities. At night, candles lit on the offerings create a mystical and solemn atmosphere. Fan Dance: This is an ancient form of folk dance. The main instrument is the fan, which can be opened or closed in pairs or one open and one closed. It can be performed individually during festivals or collectively during celebrations. Performers step out to showcase hand waving, fan fluttering, or foot movements, sometimes fast, sometimes slow, sometimes light and gentle, and at other times powerful and vigorous, in sync with the music. The audience is captivated by each movement of the artist. The entire audience is stirred by the music and dance, cheering with "ahei" (applause). Water-Carrying Dance: Originating from the Thong hala dance (a tray carrying betel) during the offering of holy water at the towers, it later combined with the act of carrying water jars in daily life, evolving into this dance form. Ethnic Instrument Performance: In addition to dance performances, the performances of the Paranưng drum and Saranai horn by Cham artists also leave a lasting impression on tourists. In the mystical My Son valley, the sounds of horns and drums resonate as if bringing the reliefs on the towers to life, transporting visitors back to the ancient sacred city. Besides enjoying the art, visitors can also participate in cultural experiences such as learning a few traditional dance moves, trying to carry water jars, wearing Cham costumes, and taking photos with artisans. After the performance, you can stroll around the tower area, listening to the guide share about the architecture, beliefs, and historical stories of each tower – a journey that is both relaxing and rich in cultural values.
